- Two Jacks: Jack of Hearts (2), Jack of Diamonds (7) = PAIR
- Two 3s: 3 of Spades (1), 3 of Diamonds (10) = PAIR


- Two 7s: 7 of Hearts (3), 7 of Diamonds (8) = PAIR

With three pairs available, I can form Two Pair. A Full House isn't possible since I lack three of a kind.

**Two Pair Calculation:**
Playing Jacks and 7s gives me the highest card values: 80 base chips plus 34 from the four cards (10 + 10 + 7 + 7), and the Blue Joker adds 58 more for a strong total.

Even accounting for the multiplier and Card Sharp's X3 boost on a second play—which would yield 860 chips initially, then 2,580 on the replay for 3,440 combined—this falls short of the 12,482 chips I need.

I need to pursue a Full House instead, which requires three of a kind plus a pair. Looking at remaining deck options, I have two Jacks in hand with two more available, and three 3s still in play.

With 5 cards out of 29 remaining that could complete a Full House, discarding my current hand to draw 5 fresh cards gives me roughly a 58% success rate. Now I'm considering which cards to keep and which to discard to maximize my chances.

I should hold onto two pairs rather than three of a kind. Keeping the Jacks and 7s seems strongest since they're higher ranked, which means discarding the 3 of Spades, 6 of Hearts, 8 of Clubs, Ace of Diamonds, and 5 of Diamonds. Though I could potentially keep the 3s instead if that offers better value.

Actually, holding three pairs gives me multiple paths to a full house—drawing another Jack, 7, or 3 would complete it. But I'm limited to keeping exactly 5 cards, so I need to commit to which two pairs maximize my odds.

The Jacks and 7s are my strongest option since they're higher ranked. I'll keep both pairs and one kicker, discarding the 3s, 6, 8, Ace, and 5.

Wait—let me verify my actual hand first. I have two Jacks, two 7s, and two 3s. If I keep just the Jacks and 7s, I'm discarding the 3 of Spades along with the other low cards.

# Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
buy_card <card_position> - Buy a card from the card section. Individual Joker cards are also bought from the card section.
buy_booster <booster_pack_position> - Buy a booster pack from the booster pack section.
buy_voucher <voucher_position> - Buy a voucher from the voucher section.
buy_and_use_consumable <consumable_position> - Buy a consumable type card (Tarot, Planet, Spectral) from the card section and use it immediately. Cannot do this if the consumable requires target hand cards.
round_select - Finish shopping and go to the round select screen.
reroll_shop - Spends the reroll cost to reroll the cards section of the shop.
